articles.headline: Tea Party Hero Is Leaving the Senate for a New Pulpit
articles.snippet: Senator Jim DeMint, a Republican from South Carolina, will lead the Heritage Foundation: a platform and a payday that the United States Senate could never provide him.
articles.abstract: Senator Jim DeMint, a Republican from South Carolina, will lead the Heritage Foundation: a platform and a payday that the United States Senate could never provide him.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — With a disappointing election in his rear view mirror and a budget compromise he could never swallow on the horizon, Senator Jim DeMint, the conservative Republican from South Carolina who helped ignite the Tea Party movement, is leaving the Senate to become president of the Heritage Foundation, a conservative research group.

articles.headline: A Big Art Lover, and Moneyman, Is Missing at the Fair
articles.snippet: Steven A. Cohen, the billionaire founder of SAC Capital Advisors and owner of a rich trove of art, is a regular at Art Basel Miami Beach. But he’s absent this year.
articles.abstract: Steven A. Cohen, the billionaire founder of SAC Capital Advisors and owner of a rich trove of art, is a regular at Art Basel Miami Beach. But he’s absent this year.
articles.lead_paragraph: MIAMI BEACH — The opening of Art Basel Miami Beach, under way here this week, looked like the start of the most glamorous doorbuster sale in history, with hundreds of V.I.P.’s streaming into the convention center wearing high-end resort casual, ready to rummage through more than 200 of the world’s most prestigious galleries.

articles.headline: In Obama’s Plan to Tax Rich, $250,000 Figure May Mislead
articles.snippet: A large majority of families making up to $300,000 — as well as hundreds of thousands of families with even greater incomes — would not pay taxes at a higher marginal rate.
articles.abstract: A large majority of families making up to $300,000 — as well as hundreds of thousands of families with even greater incomes — would not pay taxes at a higher marginal rate.
articles.lead_paragraph: President Obama’s insistence that marginal tax rates rise for families making more than $250,000 has convinced millions of affluent Americans that they are likely to be writing larger checks to the government next year.
articles.byline: By Catherine Rampell and Binyamin Appelbaum

articles.headline: Sorting Out a Chinese Puzzle in Auditing
articles.snippet: American and Canadian regulators who try to scrutinize Chinese corporations generally face a huge task getting cooperation from Chinese authorities.
articles.abstract: American and Canadian regulators who try to scrutinize Chinese corporations generally face a huge task getting cooperation from Chinese authorities.
articles.lead_paragraph: Imagine for a moment that you were auditing a company whose principal asset was trees that it would eventually cut down to sell the timber. Would you bother to verify whether the company actually owned the trees? Would you make sure that the trees the company showed to your auditors were the same trees it claimed to own?

articles.headline: S.E.C. Warns Netflix Over a Post on Facebook
articles.snippet: Netflix disclosed on Thursday that it and its chief executive, Reed Hastings, could face enforcement actions from the Securities and Exchange Commission because of a piece of business information disclosed in a Facebook post this summer.
articles.abstract: Netflix disclosed on Thursday that it and its chief executive, Reed Hastings, could face enforcement actions from the Securities and Exchange Commission because of a piece of business information disclosed in a Facebook post this summer.
articles.lead_paragraph: Reed Hastings, the chief executive of Netflix, congratulated his team for a job well done in early July. On his public Facebook page, he crowed about the one billion hours of video that subscribers watched the previous month. The message was just 43 words.
articles.byline: By Michael J. de la Merced

articles.headline: National Network for First Responders Is Years Away
articles.snippet: Planning delays, lack of money and limitations in technology have slowed the creation of a communications network for the police, firefighters and others.
articles.abstract: Planning delays, lack of money and limitations in technology have slowed the creation of a communications network for the police, firefighters and others.
articles.lead_paragraph: During Hurricane Sandy, New York police commanders could talk by radio with fire department supervisors across the city, to officials battling power failures in nearby counties and with authorities shutting down airports in New York and New Jersey.

articles.headline: Soaring Rents Drive a Boom in Apartments
articles.snippet: As part of a national rush to capitalize on rising rents, new apartment complexes are being built at the fastest pace since 2008.
articles.abstract: As part of a national rush to capitalize on rising rents, new apartment complexes are being built at the fastest pace since 2008.
articles.lead_paragraph: Houston is better known for urban sprawl than dense apartment living. But as part of a national rush to capitalize on rising rents, developers there are building thousands of apartments like those south of downtown at Camden City Centre, where 268 units will open early next year in a complex that also has two swimming pools, billiards tables, a coffee bar and a fitness center.
articles.byline: By Shaila Dewan and Nelson D. Schwartz

articles.headline: Horrific Fire Revealed a Gap in Safety for Global Brands
articles.snippet: A blaze that killed 112 workers in Bangladesh last month exposed a disconnect among retailers like Sears and Walmart, the monitoring system to protect workers and the factories filling the orders.
articles.abstract: A blaze that killed 112 workers in Bangladesh last month exposed a disconnect among retailers like Sears and Walmart, the monitoring system to protect workers and the factories filling the orders.
articles.lead_paragraph: ASHULIA, Bangladesh — The fire alarm shattered the monotony of the Tazreen Fashions factory. Hundreds of seamstresses looked up from their machines, startled. On the third floor, Shima Akhter Pakhi had been stitching hoods onto fleece jackets. Now she ran to a staircase.

articles.headline: Unused Pills Raise Issue of Disposal and Risks
articles.snippet: The pharmaceutical industry is challenging a California law that stipulates it pay for the proper disposal of leftover pills that could otherwise pose a threat to the environment.
articles.abstract: The pharmaceutical industry is challenging a California law that stipulates it pay for the proper disposal of leftover pills that could otherwise pose a threat to the environment.
articles.lead_paragraph: Brand name drug makers and their generic counterparts rarely find themselves on the same side of an issue, but now they are making an exception. They have teamed up to fight a local law in California, the first in the nation, that makes them responsible for running — and paying for — a program that would allow consumers to turn in unused medicines for proper disposal.

articles.headline: Jobless Rate Edges Down to Its Lowest Level in 4 Years
articles.snippet: Unemployment dropped to 7.7 percent as the economy continued to recover in spite of the lingering budget stalemate and the damaging effects of Hurricane Sandy.
articles.abstract: Unemployment dropped to 7.7 percent as the economy continued to recover in spite of the lingering budget stalemate and the damaging effects of Hurricane Sandy.
articles.lead_paragraph: Despite fears of a slowdown caused by gridlock in Washington, the economic recovery moved forward at a steady pace in November, pushing unemployment to its lowest level in four years.
